text.p: There could hardly be a wider gulf in managerial image between Stuart Pearce and Arsene Wenger, but the pair neatly illustrate the increasingly split personality of modern English soccer.

Saturday afternoon summed it all up perfectly. Wenger, the cultured Frenchman who has removed the blinkers from Arsenal this season, versus Nottingham Forest's Pearce, a stereotypical English defender with a passion for punk rock and a dislike of talking to the media.

The result was a 2-1 win for bottom-of-the-table Forest, although the fact a Norwegian scored both home goals made it a slightly less emphatic victory for bulldog spirit over continental sophistication.

Still, it represented a special moment for Pearce, appointed caretaker player-manager following the midweek resignation of Frank Clark despite his continued involvement in England's World Cup qualifying squad.
Known to his team-mates as "Psycho" for his uncompromising approach to the game, Pearce cheerfully admitted he could have ended his first game in charge as the butt of a thousand jokes.
When he sat down to select his first Forest team, the 34-year-old became so wrapped up in tactical planning he overlooked one crucial detail.
"When I wrote down the players I wanted, I found I had 12 names on the sheet," he joked. "You could tell I was new to management."
His final pre-match instructions to his players were scarcely of the Churchillian variety -- "Don't mess me about" -- and he has already been exposed to the hidden demands of the job.
"The last 24 hours has been pretty strange. To be honest, I enjoyed being on the pitch because no-one can hassle you or ring you there."
Such a homegrown philosophy is light years removed from Wenger's more studious approach, famous for inspiring England manager Glenn Hoddle when he was a player at Monaco.
But though Arsenal remain in second place in the table, the new poise of their football has ironically coincided with an increasing amount of trouble with referees.
Steve Bould and Tony Adams both received red cards in the space of four days last month, and Ian Wright's dismissal on Saturday added to the roll of dishonour.
Wenger suggested it was simply coincidence and said he had not seen the Wright incident.
"I can't give an opinion because I didn't see what happened, but having him sent off made it more difficult for us.
"We already had problems and, of course, it makes a difference when you're down to 10 men."
What has undoubtedly made the biggest difference to English soccer, however, has been the influx of overseas talent.

Saturday's premier league games featured goals from two Norwegians, a Frenchman, a Dane, an Italian and a Portuguese, not to mention Welsh and Northern Irish internationals Mark Hughes and Jim Magilton.

Chelsea fans, in particular, left Stamford Bridge raving about a goal from Gianfranco Zola in their 3-1 win over West Ham which reinforced Ruud Gullit's decision to sign him from Parma for 4.5 million pounds ($7.5 million) last month.
Zola totally confused West Ham captain Julian Dicks with a dazzling solo 10th minute effort, and Gullit was quick to congratulate him.
"Franco has stolen the hearts of the fans with the way he plays. He's given us something extra and I'm very happy for him."
If Zola imagines he can copy the majority of Europe's footballers and put his feet up over Christmas, however, he will be sadly disappointed.

The festive season is as packed with fixtures as ever and is often a time when traditional English stamina triumphs over continental skill. The challenge for Zola and company is to keep decorating the English game once the turkey and mince pies have disappeared.
